title: Debt purchased by another lender...
question: I have debt that has been closed by the original CC Company. But in the creditor’s notes on my cc report it states ‘purchased by another lender”. I am trying to research the Collection Company before making any payments but there is no web site for Riverwalk Holding. I was told that this company bought my debt for cents on the dollar, and that I can haggle their payment price. Is that true?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit
answers:
I have seen debts sold by the creditor, only to later be claimed by MULTIPLE debt collectors, each of which claimed to have documents that proved it was the owner. Maybe this debt buyer/collector is the legitimate owner, and may be it is not. If you do settle with this company, be sure to get a document showing that the debt has been settled in full, so that you can use this to get your credit report updated to show a zero balance and also to defend yourself if another debt collector comes calling in the future.

I represent consumers against debt collectors and debt collection lawsuits, and have never heard of this company, so I cannot affirm who they are or if they might sue you if you refuse to negotiate. Remember, if they are the actual owner of the debt, they can sue you and you will then need to defend. Of course, if there are any documents that they cannot produce to prove true ownership or if they wait too long to sue you and the statute of limitations expires, then they will lose and you wind up paying nothing.

The price that is paid by a debt buyer for a pool of debts depends on several factors, such as how recent the defaults were taken, the type of debt, the lender, the credit of the borrowers, and perhaps numerous other factors, such as if the borrowers are homeowners.

The new company may very well negotiate with you. However, you should take two things into consideration.

First (and check with your tax professional on this), if the new collective company accepts a sum less than the balance due, it may result in a taxable event known as foregiveness of debt. For example, if you owe a creditor $4,000 and it agrees to accept $2,000 in satisfaction of that debt, the creditor may issue you a form 1099 for the difference between the total debt and the settlement amount, effectively treating the $2,000 sum forgiven as income for taxation purposes.

Second, when there are sales or assignments of a bundle of debts, as here, creditors sometimes have trouble demonstrating that they own the debt. Should you be unable to negotiate a resolution and the matter enters litigation, it would be prudent to seek proof of ownership of the debt as part of discovery. In the absence of that proof, the creditor who claims to have purchased the debt may lack standing, i.e. the right, to commence the lawsuit in the first place. In high volume purchases, this issue can create a real problem for creditors and may justify a reasonable resolution.
